First and foremost I don't believe in real world paranormal stuff only cognitive ghosts/gods and information based entities that manipulate reality by subtly using people and groups of people as a vessel. Reality level paranormal stuff is just a red-herring to cover for real higher order beings.

>Be me
>Senior year of highschool
>be dating the girl of my dreams
>A sperg but in the cute innocent way
>Is a legit genius, Iq is tested at 150 but its over that
> when she was tested as a kid she started answering questions wrongs after the tester started reacting weird
>Based, and we fell deep in love

>On day after we hooked on a cool summer night in my car as you do in high school
> she confides something to me
>Ever since childhood she's seen things others can't
>blurry ghost like figures walking around
>what she calls Gnomes and other weird creatures and phenomena
> Also has what I now realize could be called a Tulpa, since childhood
>I wont use it's real name
>But its form is this cute cartoon orange man drawing
>Has an independent personality and everything
>she can also visualize objects in reality
>At the time was using this power to design a micro fluidic chip for detecting cancer

>Aside from believing these thing are real she has no other strange beliefs or delusions
>Completely and utterly sane
>Only other belief being the concept of greenness and the ocean
>Basically in humanity there are a few people who are in constant state of taking in the patterns of reality and humanity
>They see inevitabilities, and hyper abstractions that can from analogies between any two thing. Basically constantly engaging with things as the thing between things.
>These people usually end up as authors and poets
>or simply kill themselves because there is no one to relate to
>At first I was skeptical
>Then intrigued
>And then completely seduced by the idea of greenness

[part 1]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>1 year passes, it's the summer after my first year of college and I'm back in town
>I've been flirting with the idea, but never had the time to explore it
>Parents are pestering me to get a job, but I say fuck it and spend the entire summer trying to enter the ocean
>At first I tried reading western poetry to get there but she said I was being stupid about it and recommend I suffi peotry.
>It takes like a day of reading it while completely shunning the logicality of my brain to reach it
>you must accept every word and ever line as a truth to reach it
>All of a sudden it creeps up on me, a complete unfocusing of the mind like blurring your eyes
>Then in a moment, I see beneath the material plane

>Everything is a finger of a hand and all is interconnected beneath the thin veil of the oceans surface
>everything exists in reference to everything else: all concepts and all objects.
>materialism is the leaves upon stems evolving out from a tree
>all trees are fed by water
>all water flows back to the great ocean
>Be it by river or by rain
>it is inevitable

>However that was not the final step of my journey only The beginning. there's a lot I've seen but one thing stands out
> something I’m somewhat afraid of doing again as a result of the existential terror I felt afterwards.
>I don't believe I spoke to god
>This isn't some reality level phenomena
> and I'm not a skitzo like many people on this board
>I believe what I see in reference to what I can rationally deduce to be true
>However I believe I communicated with entities, while not on any drugs, that exist within me
[part 2]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>After having entered the ocean many things changed
>However one thing kept recurring
>I felt like something was pinging me from inside my brain
>It felt in my heart like a younger sibling knocking on my door to play with him
>however my door was thick and made of dense oak
>And it wasn't a door at all but my skull

>One night I'm lying in bed with my lights on
>eventually I say fuck it let my mind grow blurrier than ever before
>short tangent
>you can control how blurry it is kind of like willing your body to move forwards or backwards except in a higher mental dimension.
>Once blurry a new forwards and backwards exists. The Macrocosmic direction and the Microcosmic. Like various levels of fractal granularity.
>If you dont get this wiki the Fractal dimension and Koch Curves.
>ok back on track

>I close my eyes and let myself fall into a near dream state
>Rather then controlling I concede mental control to the source of the pinging
>Kind of like unlocking a door and cracking it open
>Then after some vague visualization I open my eyes
>Gradually I start seeing the souls, it's the closest word I can think of, of everything I'm looking at as an overlay in my minds eye
>they morph into organic moving creature that seem to reflect my unconscious selfs grasp of them
> However soon after I meet my first being

>It a towering lanky marionette jester.
>Its dressed in all black with a white face
> its eyes are large dark pits and its mouth is sewn shut into a wide grin.
>It's hands are in white silk gloves
>It tries to scare me, in the way an older cynical man might try to scare young children with stories of what lurks in the dark
[part 3]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
> It points to the darkness outside of my widow, under my bed, and everywhere else something might hide as if to imply something is there.
>It finds amusement out of this but I don't sense malice
>rather boredom, nihilism, and some attempt to protect through fear
>this occurs for a while, and not to brag, I'm unaffected by it's antics

>however I realize it is not me protecting myself, but a pterodactyl with the wingspan and size of a large dog.
>with every attempt from the jester to scare me it would swoop down and hug me shielding me from any fear
>I pet it's head and felt its nature
>young, naive, kind and courageous
>It felt the most purely benevolent of the creatures I met

>Next up were two that I never got to know well
>I fell completely out of reality by closing my eyes
>Materialized onto the steps of a Roman/greek like marble palace reminiscent of Thomas Cole's Consummation of Empire
>In it on a throne was a aquatic king with a sea shell for a head and strong masculine bearded face
>It had a weird trident like object in one hand and some musical instrument I can't place my finger on in the other
>It just looked at me slightly amused, but uninterested and I went on my way
>He felt moral, wise, just, and regal however more passive than the pterodactyl or jester

>Next was a pixie like creature
>I only saw her for a moment but she was beautiful yet child like in demeanor
>Kind of like a mix between the innocence and kindness of the pterodactyl and the mischievousness of the jester
[Part 4]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Finally last was the most profound of all of them
>at the core of my being was the god of this realm and the one who was knocking
>It was a baby radiating light and covered in migrating eyes
> Sitting atop a throne at the bottom of the ocean it babbled and clapped its hand as if it had seen both it's father and mother for the first time
> In that moment I realized all the creatures before where like the semi independent fingers of this god/baby and it was the palm
>I also realized it was trapped alone in this world and grew it's fingers to play with me and gain some contact with someone
> It was my unconscious neglected and lonely as a result of the rationalism of civilization that shuns the personal spiritual elements of man
> I felt a deep sense of grief as to how it was trapped there all alone
>Therefore I embraced it and it entered my body
> I became a hermaphrodite
> then grew pregnant my belly slowly swelling
> Then I rebirthed it and embraced it again

>Finally I fell asleep and woke up the next day with a deep existential dread
>Something was warning me I should slow down and there was an inherent danger to what I was doing
>I felt the presence of monsters of the ocean that eat those naive enough to explore too fast, driving them to suicide
>Or wielding the group psychosis of humanity against them
> therefore I slowed down and saw many-things
> I've started reading about complex systems, a mathematical/scientific field combining computation, evolution, and natural systems
> next is the history of psychology
>However I feel comfortable enough to share this
> Over the past year I've seen so much, I think its time to start deliberately writing it down if only for myself so I can make sense of it all.
[End]

You're assuming that the fungi would wipe out the human populations and settlements, no? If you look at parasitism in general, you'll notice that most parasites, or at least the most successful ones are the ones that don't kill the host and live in them for as long as possible. Killing the host would put the parasite at a disadvantage, especially in the context of humans since when we notice that something is wrong, we tend to make medical treatments for it. Of course, the only parasites that would be left are ones that are extremely virulent, not as deadly, and not very noticeable. Given that we exist, it's safe to assume that we had managed to eradicate the more deadly specimens that had suddenly appeared in the past, and that of course includes viral and bacterial outbreaks.

Instead of saying "this is the exact thing that happened and we're 100% sure and everyone else is wrong", you could say "current mainstream opinion is X for reasons A, B, and C, however we think Y is more likely for reasons D, E, and F". Perhaps counterintuitively, a writing style that is a tad unsure comes across as way more convincing than one that boasts about how assuredly right it is.

posts.name: Peribsen

>>33753607

So to the first bit regarding evolution happening differently in space than on the ground, or in a cave. Ionizing radiation. There's a large amount of research already done on how radiation changes genetic properties of these fungi. Look up Chernobyl and Cryptococcus. That's the same cryptococcus neoformans that is proving to be a deadly pathogen by the way. There are other studies related to virulence increase after radiation exposure, I believe that was saccharomyces but it's another dimorphic and human pathogenic yeast so same logic applies.

Now put a species in space, where there's no atmosphere to shield against rads. The right conditions and spores could survive dessicated for an extremely long time. Meteor hits a water supply, just for example, and now you've got panspermia. Difficult odds? Sure, but not anymore than the odds of a new species just popping up out of nowhere. The clades that were mentioned for Candida Auris are odd because they showed up roughly simultaneously but had already been through enough generations to be distinct genetically.

Vancouver 1999 that was mentioned a thread or two ago is another good key in for panspermia. A large scale Cryptococcus Neoformans outbreak (largest ever for overgrowth in immunocompetent population actually) that still has no satisfactory explanation.

And sure you're going to run into resistance in the settings of concern you mentioned. But that's very different than a species just popping up en masse in areas it shouldn't be in.

I really think that consideration needs to be given to the cave origins as well. I stand by the origin point of dimorphic fungi being potentially not here originally though. They don't line up with the other fungi very well and have some odd traits. Like keying in on 95F for certain biological processes, being able to survive environments that standard dimorphic fungi can't, and even having multi stage processes to obtain energy/ATP from a living host.

posts.name: Peribsen
posts.com:
>>33753607

And on the Taforalt bit.

It's an interesting dig site and it's well known to be the oldest human dumping ground. Concurrent use is about 360K years. And the oldest genetic material in all of Africa to date comes from that exact site. And for whatever reason they decided keeping pigeons was a good idea. The caves are known for it, and pigeons are specifically known as carriers of zoonotic yeasts - candida and cryptococcus in particular.

Here's why it's so key to what I focus on. I believe that humans were actually better at immune function in the past. For some pathogens like the type of fungi we're studying, that may not have been that long ago overall.

There's are specific immune responses that get leveraged by these fungi. Primarily th-17s are the cells affected and errors there allow inflammation to go haywire. The way this plays into the dates from Taforalt is the population that resided there had high 90% rate of dental cavities. Cavities and dental issues for inflammation and decay are now being tied to candida as the catalyst (and I'll bet a couple others show up under scrutiny). Candida started the party, the rest of the germs show up to join in.

Now here's the tally. You can't have tooth decay in its accepted definition without candida present. If your immune system is functioning correctly your th-17s should be able to take care of fungal spores way before tooth decay ever sets in. However, the population at Taforalt is the earliest record of a population having a massive amount of tooth decay at around 17,500 years ago. And at a rate of 97%. There is not an earlier record of these types of cavities at this scale available, once there is I'll be revising my research appropriately.

It all boils down to firsts. Taforalt is the earliest genetic record of humans in Africa, it is the earliest record of massive dental failures thousands of years before agriculture, and there is a zoonotic disease vector present for nearly 20,000 years.

I use a foot bath with 2tbsp. Borax (20 mule team unscented), 2tbsp baking soda and also dump some ACV in there.

Before you soak your feet, rough up the nails in question with a nail file. Soak for 40 minutes or so, so the nail softens up. Start with a new pair of shoes after that, and use a mixture of borax and baking soda for a foot powder. Put some in your socks and some in your shoes.

It works. You just have to be patient as new nail growth takes time.

Infohazards are an interesting concept. Fairly certain most people reading this will probably know of Roko's Basilisk. But for those who don't and are wondering "anon, how can a mere idea put you at risk?", allow me to introduce you to another infohazard.

Imagine if you will, a cognitive parasie— a psychological parasite. An idea that clings to your mind, making you obsessed over it. You could be reading a novel, and boom, a concept in that novel sticks to you and makes your mind think about it over and over. Even when you need to concentrate on something else, your mind keeps ruminating on it. Your grades start to suffer, as you can only think of it, you can't hold conversations anymore because all you can talk about is it, you end up neglecting basic needs because it is taking over that much of your mind. Your life is essentially destroyed, because this one concept you can't get out of your mind.

You could not possibly predict what could get you to such a state, and even if you could, it would already be too late. You couldn't trust any piece of information, because you might accidentally stumble upon it. Hell, you couldn't even trust me— for all you know, I could very well be infected by such a parasite, and my talking about it could be the way it spreads to you.
Doesn't it make you wonder all the potential this concept could have? All the stories you could write with it? It wouldn't even end at the story, as it would leave the reader wondering if they could have possibly caught the parasite. Doesn't it just fill your head with different stories and different scenarios to infect readers with the parasite? And what's more, if a story is good enough, readers might even expand on the concept, as if evolving and mutating the parasite.


Doesn't it pique your interest, anon?

posts.name: The Nobody
posts.com:
>>33771353
>why is the whole thing tied to feeling dread?
Emotions are created by the brain in response to physical sensations, and they are modulated by the context in which they are felt. Dread however, is only in small part an emotion. It is largely a pain reflex and an attention modifier. This is what makes dread so difficult to deal with, it amplifies its own emotional context.

As for why sleep paralysis is comes with dread, it's because of the physical discomfort. You are restrained, your heart is stressed, and your breathing is strained. Through proper attention and awareness all of these physical discomforts can be lessened / ignored. The dread can dissipate, and it can even become a thing of the past. These were my experiences.

posts.name: The Nobody

>>33771502
>what you mean by "attention modifier"?
That's the most important part. Dread restricts one's attention and generally produces paranoid thoughts as a consequence. Simply calming down is often not enough to counteract the demand dread puts on one's attention. There is a mastery of focus that comes in to play as well.

I have had experiences that I would like to understand.

I heard from a tv show that sleep paralysis happens when you wake up from a nightmare.

I have experienced waking up from a nightmare with sleep paralysis and a sense of a threatening presence, perhaps a looming darkness or dark figures and a feeling of fear. That all went away when I had asserted my will and managed to move, breaking out of that state.

However, I also experienced something else when I was a child.

Sometimes while trying to fall asleep, shadowy figures dragged me to a flaming pit blocking the doorway to my room and down the "fire hole" (as I called it as a child) into a nightmare. I had nightmares multiple times a week, and this is how many of them began, like a frame tale.

I was scared, suffering, and losing sleep. That may be how my insomnia started. I could run to my parents to tell them and get a hug, but I still had to escape from these nightmares that I occasionally got dragged into by figures similar to the presence or presences I sensed during sleep paralysis.

I started lucid dreaming as defense against all the nightmares, and sometimes I could control the dream. Usually after going lucid, I wake up, because I realized that I was dreaming.

Sometimes I would get stuck in a nightmare and have fight to get out. One time I was stuck in like Escher Battlezone 2 (from like Win 95) but all the lines were burning red, and there were dark figures that looked like the ones that dragged me into that nightmare. I thought they wanted to keep me there and hurt me. So I imagined summoning a tank, (I was like 10 so a tank seemed like the most powerful option even in the non-euclidian geometey of the landscape, plus it's mobile.) So i blasted the presences (honestly they looked like straight up Grays except red and black instead of gray.)

I have varied dreams now and few nightmares, and sometimes I lucid dream. I am also schizoaffective but that was not until I turned 29. Mabye irrelevant.

There is no entity sitting on your chest, you're seeing it a dream, while you are awake.

It is easy to become afraid when you can't move like you expect to be able to, but once you start feeling fear, the manifestations of your dream will simply compound that feeling as they would with any other feeling.

I was having a very lucid dream of walking in a big, misty, beautiful architectural expanse with white tile and fountains and the like, still listening to this podcast (the audio was coming through into the dream). Suddenly I'm in back in room, in my closet, out of my body, this no longer feels like a dream but the real location. Still can hear the podcast. Then I'm instantly pulled back into my bed, and there is now a woman sat at a desk at the edge of my bed, her face was obscured by an indefinite object like a laptop or typewriter. I can feel her watching me. This paralyzed me and I just laid there still listening to the podcast until the experience ended. Was definitely spooked having never had an experience like this before and only vaguely knowing about sleep paralysis as a phenomenon that existed, definitely knew nothing about out of body experiences and I feel like if I hadn't been desk-hagged and allowed to move around freely I probably would've been super mindblown, especially since I was a total atheist at the time and for years after. Experience did always stick with me though as being very strange and supernatural feeling.

The human sources of knowledge are three: sound sense perception, reliable reporting, and logic & reasoning.
These names and concepts are not identical to the objects or properties they represent — they are merely what we use to help us understand and communicate about reality; concepts we use are not inherent or necessary aspects of reality itself, they are simply convenient tools that we use to make sense of the world around us. Objects and properties of reality do exist, but rather independently of the names and concepts we use to describe them.
The mind possesses necessary knowledge of the external reality mediated to it by the senses, of its own innate logical principles, and of whatever has reached it by way of massively recurrent transmission.
Human reason is limited and can be problematic and lead to errors, biases, and false assumptions; reason can not be the sole source of truth (by virtue of the intuitive experience), but instinctively recognizes necessary and self-evident truths.
The intuitive experience is the mind using innate knowledge to abstract universal concepts, from empirical knowledge provided, to form judgments (impressions) of what it holds as mental representations of external reality.
Just as sensory perception allows us to gather information about the world around us, reliable reporting allows us to gather accurate and consistent information from others. In both cases, the more reliable the sense we use and the more reliable the source, the more certain we can be about the information we are receiving, and the impression it forms.
Impressions are rational if and only if they cohere to the intuitive experience.
Evidence is only necessary to validate impressions if anomalies appear to disrupt their coherency.

>>33778469
An existent is that which is itself; an impossible existent cannot exist by virtue of what it is; a possible existent can or cannot exist by virtue of what it is. This is obtained through the innate logical principles commonly known as the "Classical Laws of Logic", "Principle of Sufficient Reason", and "Causal Principle":

An existent:

Proposition 1)
Exists by virtue of what it is

Proposition 2)
Does not exist by virtue of what it is

Conclusion)
By the Law of Non-Contradiction,
Proposition 1 & Proposition 2 cannot both be true (or both false) at the same time and in the same way.

By the Law of the Excluded Middle, there are 3 types of existents:

The first type of existent would be "Necessary",
where the first proposition is true and the second proposition is false,
as the "Necessary existent" exists by virtue of what it is.

The second type of existent would be "Impossible",
where the first proposition is false and the second proposition is true,
as the "Impossible existent" does not exist by virtue of what it is.

The third type of existent would be "Possible",
where the existent can or can not exist, by virtue of what it is.
By the Principle of Sufficient Reason and the Causal Principle,
(which together state that everything must have an explanation for its cause of existence)
the cause of the emergence of a Possible existent must be an extrinsic specifier.
Therefore, their emergence is due to a cause external to itself,
where the existent would be "Dependent" or "Contingent", by virtue of what it is.


Affirmation of these principles while denying these types of existents leads to a framework of infinite regress and no explanation for the grounding of truth, the emergence of temporal events, or the emergence of existents.

These innate logical principles are for supposing coherent abstraction as to what accepts its existence being actualised in reality; such that the cause of any proposition must be non-arbitrary. While their descriptions vary in application and the concepts conveyed in a paradigm that accepts them can describe them in alignment in various manners, they help us to understand the nature of reality and the ways in which things come into being, as well as their objective and subjective qualities. They are not separate things, but rather different ways of describing the same underlying reality.

What is the purpose of reasoning and logic if not to arrive at the most accurate and coherent understanding of reality, and how can we be sure that our reasoning and logic are reliable if we do not have an innate understanding of the fundamental nature of reality and the laws that govern it?
If our innate knowledge and logical principles did not accurately reflect the nature of reality, how could we have any confidence in the conclusions we draw about the world and ourselves?

Would not a reliance on arbitrary principles ultimately lead to a lack of coherence and inconsistency in our understanding of the world and our knowledge?
Is it not more logical and coherent to trust in principles that are grounded in reason and have a rational basis, rather than those that are arbitrary and lack such justification?

Indeed, these principles (which are necessary truths by their very nature) are innate and must be grounded in the cause of externality itself.

>Feel free to suggest resources
Resources:
Books:
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel
https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams
No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission. Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason
https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
This one is a collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. Part grimoire, part reverence. Contains art and accounts by different people.

Videos:
Who is Lilith? Ancient Origins by Esoterica
https://youtu.be/n1EKccz4fS0
A fairly extensive history on her historical origins
The Untold Truth of Lilith by Grunge
https://youtu.be/01guwJbp_ug
A short video intended for a popular audience
Goes over her myth and general nature
Goddess Lilith - What she likes, how to contact
https://youtu.be/75bnMRPRiDk
A simple, short to the point video that rings true to my experiences.
My Experiences Workiing with Lilith
https://youtu.be/EHol9LrpWks
One woman's account of her experience

>feminine sexuality and other weird stuff
For me it's been partially the opposite. Since working with her recently, I've been confronted with bisexual urges, and I'm still unsure how to reconcile them. It hasn't gotten to the point of feeling attracted to women in person, but nonetheless, my spiritual experiences lately have me questioning my sexual orientation.

It's embarrassing to admit, but I used to find women somewhat repulsive. I've always admired those who exemplify masculine virtues, and often saw women as the opposite, taking advantage of men's strength like parasites, subconsciously seducing their will just to satisfy their own needs. And I felt deeply ashamed of my sexuality as I recognised that same neediness within myself.

Even so, I still had to deal with gender dysphoria somehow. I already sought help from others when I was 14, but even then I could only wait as I lost things that felt important to me. But when I was 17, perhaps in a lapse of judgement, I turned to the occult. It was just a prayer to attempt to form a pact, and not even directed towards anyone in particular. But since then, my life began to change drastically, and I found relief that I didn't even think was possible.

As the wish I'd once made reached a satisfactory conclusion, and Lilith offered to guide me towards a new purpose, I thanked her and began to show my appreciation for her more. I thought I accepted myself now that I'm finally at peace with my body, only to feel lost again as spiritual experiences confront me with all sorts of sides of myself that I don't know how to reconcile. I'd have been content to ignore them for the rest of my life, but now I'm unsure how I'm supposed to proceed anymore. And although I recall her offer to guide me, I'm reluctant as I fear I'll be forced to face even more.

That's what I get for being dishonest with myself; for being so easily seduced as my contradictions are exposed.

>>33737944
I always struggled to relate to transgender people. Dysphoria was primarily a physical thing for me that ceased after my surgery, so I find the focus on stereotypes asinine and childish.

Two years ago, my older brother asked me to strangle his neck as hard as I can. He was curious if his neck muscles are stronger than my arms. I refused as it made me uncomfortable.
A year later, I felt scared as I realised how weak I am physically. But when I told my fiancé that I wanted to try building abs to boost my confidence, he was against it; he said he dislikes muscles on women. I lost motivation, as I realised I can never be as strong as him anyway.

I dislike alcohol, but knowing I'm way too hard on myself, I drank half a glass of champagne yesterday, hoping it would loosen me up a bit. The results were as agonising as I expected. It was far too little for me to lose control, but it became slightly harder for me to suppress my unwanted emotions. As they raged inside of me, I snuck away from my family and isolated myself. I forced myself to remain silent and still, but the storm inside only worsened.

When I returned, my brother noticed I was tense. He said to let out my anger by hugging him as hard as I can. So I embraced him, as if trying to crush him.
In that moment, I felt glad I'm physically weak. "I don't have to hold back. I don't have be afraid I'll hurt others, if this is all I can do", I thought.
But then, he said repeatedly: "You're strong. Those hormones didn't affect you nearly as badly as I thought." He sounded so relieved.

My brother is the strongest man I know. If I can be strong in his eyes even without training after 7 years of having less testosterone than most women, then I shouldn't belittle myself.
So I've decided to start working out and learn martial arts. It doesn't matter if I won't be as strong as I'd have been as a man; transitioning gave me other things that are more important to me. Even so, I still want to become my best self.

I attempted physical transmutation a few years ago, as I was curious whether it might work. However, I discontinued my efforts after a few weeks, as it caused severe inflammation and pieces of dead skin falling off in a particular area. Not only was the pain becoming unbearable, but I realised what I was doing was highly dangerous, as it was becoming difficult to even urinate. After discontinuing my magick, which consisted of daily energy work in a deep trance, the symptoms subsided in just a day.

My conclusions are that it's far more efficient to change physical things by physical means, and spiritual things by spiritual means. Not only that, but it's dangerous to attempt to remove body parts with magick; it's no different from convincing those parts of your body to destroy themselves, with no guarantee of actually getting the results you want. In my experience, physical surgery is both safer and much less painful in comparison. However, based on other results I got such as a sudden spurt of breast growth, I do think it can be useful for healing.

You posted here a while ago and clarified that you're not interested in physically transitioning, nor in changing spiritually. Perhaps it could be useful for you to try to understand why you think you want to be a biological woman, and find (other) positive ways for you to fulfil the underlying needs.

The pre-tribulation rapture versus mid-tribulation rapture debate is absolutely melting my brain off.

Many evangelical Christians in modern times preach that the rapture will occur before the 7-year tribulation, but some claim that there are convincing parallels and mentions within the Bible that lend to the Rapture NOT occurring before the tribulation but rather at the halfway point, ~3.5 years in.

When the disciples got into the boat in John 6, they embarked on a seven mile journey across the Sea of Galilee. At the exact halfway point, (about three or four miles in), they see Jesus walking on the water and become afraid, but as soon as he says "It is I," they let him into the boat and suddenly, they are transported to the other shore, despite having 3.5 miles to go.

How does the above passage not lend itself to a midtribulationist mindset? What else could this story mean if it isn't saying this? Note also that Jesus walking on water has an imagery in common with Him riding on a cloud in the sky (which is itself referred to as the waters above back in Genesis)

posts.com:
Today is the Feast of holy Theophany. It takes place 12 days after the Feast of the Nativity, Christmas, as the culmination of Christ's epiphany to the world as God.

There were three epiphanies Jesus made indiacating he was the Christ before his earthly ministry (symbolizing the Holy Trinity). The first was in his birth, announced by angels to simple shepherds tending their flocks.

The second epiphany was the Star of Bethlehem, that shone for all to see and wonder, it was not an ordinary star, because it could change location unnaturally. It was instead a divine power, and a group of Zoroastrian priests, the magi or three kings followed it to a small manger in the Judean town of Bethlehem, where a child had been born.

The final, and great epiphany was in the Theophany. In Theophany, the Trinity as God is finally revealed in its fullness. Christ goes down into water and sanctified it, our High Priest, filled with the Godhead. The Holy Spirit descends as a dove, God's love, and a voice declares that Jesus is his Beloved Son. And cannot we not see? Those who have read the scriptures know this echoes in Genesis 1, God the Holy Spirit hovers above the primordial waters of chaos, and God created the world through his Logos. Christ's baptism was his second greatest act of recreation after his resurrection. The word's "Let there be light" Stand in analogy to "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased." God's Image copy, the Son, who shares in God's essence from eternity and is God. The Trinity is God.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: OP here. Forgot to include the fact that Theophany is the second oldest feast of the Church after Pascha of course which is actually apostolic in origin. Theophany began around the early 2nd century, in Egypt, among the Christians communities there and spread. It began because of the yearly reading cycle of the holy scriptures (i.e. Lectionary). Mark chapter 1 was part of the daily read on January 6th and so it became a date to celebrate his baptism. Eventually it got tied into his birth and the visiting of the magi too which led to Christmas. Each Church developed its own traditions around these ancient holidays.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Fun fact: Great Lent probably began as a post-Theophany fast but due to its proximity with Easter, got lumped in with a bunch of other local Christian fasting periods and became a pre-Easter fast instead. There's a reason the period is still heavily associated with Jesus fasting in the desert, it begins after the Holy Spirit drew Jesus in the wilderness to fast 40 days.

>>33742794
It would seem you would be indeed a quivk learner but also have difficulty with concentration and focus even when you know you should get to work on something and set yourself at the desk.

To better study, it would be good to, instead of procrastinating, integrate your personal research time and your study time and bounce back and forth. Trying to exclusively focus upon work for a session without the pressure of an imminent deadline may result in agitation to the point of abandoning studying altogether. So when studying alone, it might be good to spend 10 minutes on fun stuff, then switch to ten minutes of studying, then another break, etc.---making use of "breaks" but instead thinking of it as just doing both at the same time: multitasking.

You may also benefit from studying in a small group who have enough discipline not to let the study sessions get derailed.

>>33740539
That period of time, you may experience yourself feeling an odd, faint sense of melancholy. Ypu may dwell about problems occurring in your life and any that might be cropping up in the project. The mood may get depressive at times, but in that particular span of a few weeks or so that you've selected, you may feel a distinct motivation to push through no matter what.

You may experience it like the bounce of a ball. You fall and hit the ground, but immediately rise back up and continue going upward and onward.

You must be naturally adept at problem-solving, perhaps surprisingly anal and detail-oriented. You should have an affinity for the use of metrics and data. My recommendation would be to keep close tabs on the metrics of the development of your project and have a good sense of what anomalies are so that you can quickly formulate plans to squash them when they arise.

Also don't neglect self-care. Keep your office space very fresh and envigorating. Think about investing in scented candles or incense, noise-cancelling headphones with ocean waves ambience, plenty of coffee and water, a comfortable seat, well-ventilated workspace, and regular food.

If you have teammates you may be liable to rubbing them the wrong way or getting cross with them about something or other. Keeping yuorself personally pleased will allow you to keep work frustrations and life frustrations completely separate and allow you to better judge whatever conflicts arise in the workplace for what they are. People can be overly sensitive so you need to be prepared to be an adult and show them where they're wrong, responsibly.

Aquarius sun and ascendant both mean you're influenced by Aquarius energy. Your sun sign is your core identity, while your ascendant is how you present yourself to the world and your outer personality.

If you have an Aquarius sun, you'll probably be a rebel with a strong sense of self. You might be seen as unconventional or nonconformist, and you'll probably be really innovative and open-minded. You might be drawn to activities that allow you to think outside the box.

If you have an Aquarius ascendant, you'll PRESENT yourself as independent and offbeat. You might have a quirky or eccentric appearance, and you'll approach life and new experiences in a unique way. You might be detached and objective in your initial reactions to people and situations.

Your sun will show more in your sense of self, and your ascendant will show more in how you present yourself to the world.

BUT That said, it's not just you presenting it, people around you will see it magically due to astrology bullshit. Even if you're not quirky in any way, they'll still perceive you as it. For example, I'm a Leo rising, and I'm Capricorn sun. For whatever fucking reason, even if I'm in the back of the room all eyes go on me even though I don't want that at all. >>33769702
There's a bit of a fractal in Astrology called derivative houses. The 12th house is stuff hidden from us, secret, subconscious etc. The 6th house is the 12th house from the 7th.

If you pretend the 7th house (relationships with others) is the first house, then it's 12th house is your 6th house if that makes sense. That's why it isolates as you're literally hidden from people.

Another thing that causes it is if your ruler of the 7th is actually in your 12th. Any house ruled by planets in the 12th gets hard shut down.
